climbs.name: Wet Stone Wall
climbs.fa: Ryan Frost Joe French Nate Brown

content.description:
Hooking here, choss there, runout free-climbing in chimneys, long pitches, bush wrangling, upside down lost arrows in wet rock... The ledge atop the arch is an amazing campsite. However, it happens to be smack in the waterfall if it rains! Beware the spring and or rain...

youtube.com/watch?v=0Depejjâ€¦
content.protection: 45 bolts left on the wall: 25 for anchors, 8 for rap anchors, 12 lead bolts... Big nailing rack: 12 each beak, 18 LAs, plenty of angles, few blades, Ztons, hooks, bolt kit, 4 each little cams to 1BD, 3 each medium cams, 2each big cams, 60m ropes mandatory...
content.location: Far right side of Streaked Wall

climbs.name: Tale of the Scorpion
climbs.fa: Dave Webster, Rick Nelson, Jeff Mayhew April 1990

content.description:
The Streaked Wall

is the most intimidating wall in the park. It is severely overhanging and requires full commitment. Once you leave the ground retreat is not an option.

The route begins off Rubicon ledge and arches at what seems like 45 degrees across a beautifully blank wall. There is nothing but a solitary crack and big air.

The first and third pitches are the technical cruxes but each pitch involves a good bit of work. All but the last 3 pitches are A3.

Many of the belay and lead bolts have been replaced.

There are many "holes" on the route. Bring plenty of #2 sawed-off angles to drop into them.
content.protection: Blades, beaks, angles, cams to #4, hooks, bolt kit, and more. Basically, come armed for bear.

content.description: Technically may be the hardest route on the wall. Severly committing, hard direct start, big runouts... Whilst climbing Good Friday the 13th, one could potentially rip the whole pitch! Woah! To top it all off, after having fried your brain, you have to do some mandatory 5.9 climbing at the top of the wall!
content.protection: As per original Mugs topo "come armed for bear"
content.location: Left most of the leaning routes

content.description: Hard, thin, dangerous, bottoming, puckering. This route is prone to destruction and will not last. Pitch two contains a pile of loose choss over a ledge that could break your legs(the ledge or choss or both that is...). The cracks are bottoming and were rurp-thin to begin with in spots. The bolt ladders are total shit-- eight-to-ten holes between bolts. Failing beak holes to boot.
content.protection: Thin, filed aid pro, big rack...
content.location: Third of four from left to right
